div.head: The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

div.head: Hall's Sanitary Washable Distemper
div.p: Made in 70 Colors
An artistic wall covering.
This celebrated water paint is made in two qualities for Inside and Outside work

HALL’S SANITARY WASHABLE DISTEMPER is rapidly superseding wall papers in all tastefully furnished homes. It is made in 70 artistic tints, and only requires the addition of water to make it ready for use. It is quickly and easily applied with a whitewash brush, with half the labour and at one third the cost of paint. HALL’S DISTEMPER ensures cleanliness, and is pleasing to the eye. It appeals alike to artistic and practical house decoration. HALL’S DISTEMPER is of special value in hot climates. Owing to its cool, pleasing colours, great weather-resisting and germ-destroying properties, it lends itself to every kind of wall, wood, brick or stone coating, possessing all the advantages of paint, colour- wash, and disinfectant at one third the cost of oil paint. It never blisters in the hottest sun, and the fact that it can be washed adds greatly to its sanitary advantages.
Supplied in Tins and Iron Kegs.
Sole Manufacturers :
SISSONS BROTHERS & Co., Ltd., HULL.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

div.head: THE GERMAN COLONIES.
div.p: The Herero rebellion in 8outh-We*t Afrioa has now oontinned more than a year and a half; and, so far as oan be judged from the reports of the German Commanders thfcre, it is far from being subdued yet Another draft of offioere and men has been shipped fiom Hamburg within the last few days : and these are to be supplemented daring the present

Empire, they oan achieve their ultimate enda of embarrassing and discrediting a policy which they hate. In the opinion of many, both in Germany and England, who have studied the oversea expansion of the Empire, the aafety of the nation at home is being jeopardised : and it is freely admitted that, while a great people might be oontent to run some risks if they oould see any prospect of each a future snocesa as has attended the British colonial policy, the results at present achieved do not give any reason for hope. The stream of German emi- gration still flows mainly to the United 8tatee; and though the young man who crosses the Atlantio holds fast to his family connections in Europe, and preserves a cer- tain sentimental affection for the Fatherland, he qniokly loses all interest in, or beoomee an onoompromiaing opponent of, the dreams of a Greater Germany that are cherished at home. As to that Greater Germany itself, the ideal was oonoeived by a few University professors, strong in their belief of the moral power of the Tentonio people, and regretful that the foroe of the nation was dissipated in internal quarrels. It was changed into action by Bismarck and the present Emperor, who enoonraged emigration to Booth America and the Australasian Islands. The Monroe dootrine stopped the former; the intense patriotism of the Bagliah in Australia showed the danger of the latter : and Germany was foroed to tarn elsewhere. At the present day there are three oolonial projects on hand. There is the movement for closer colonisation of Afrioa, assisted by Imperial subsidy, and the development of trade with the still in- dependent parts of that oontinent, until a Protectorate beoomee possible that wiU secure German oommeroe to the cxolasion of all others. There is the hope of expansion in China, which a few years ago was hailed by the more sanguine spirits as a land destined to fall to Germany, as India hat fallen to Eagland; the Japanese victories and the fear of a Chinese Benasoenoe have, however, ended all thoughts of an Eastern Empire. Finally, there is the very curious project that aims at Aria Minor. This latter, has been ventilated of late in some of the German newspapers; and it apparently prooeeds from the idea, that in the event of the Turkish Empire be- coming disintegrated, Germany would And her opportunity in stepping forward as the up- holder of Mohamedan unity in all parts of the worid—reoriving, not unnaturally, a fall quid pro qao for services rendered. In Germany itself; there is a noisy section of the pnblio whioh explains and applauds such schemes to that mass of the nation whioh cares for none of these things. At Berlin, indeed, the oracles are dumb; the Emperor seldom alludes to oolonial expansion ; bnt the expo- nents of “World Politics” are not slow to intsr- pret his silenoe. Assisted perhaps by a j ndidoua hint from headquarters, they deolare that Ger- many is now the determining voioe in Euro- pean affaire; that in the world at large her ship- ping has already^ rpaased that of Franoe, and is beginning to ran a neok-and-neok reoe with England; and that Germanism, whioh has spent oenturies in maturing, is now ripe for the con- quest of the world. We do not believe that the German people will be oarried away by such wild talk. We are oonvinoed that the moat advanoed and most educated parts of the Gorman oommunity have no love for the “mailed fist” whioh has been too freely in evidenoe. The dream of a Greater Germany has intoxioated many worthy persons; and it ia not surprising that after the "great years,” when the victories over Austria, Den- mark, end Franoe bad been accomplished, some should believe that all paths wonld be easy for the oonqnering Teutons. Bat disillu- sion has followed. The sterility of the colonies that have been aoquired, the impossibility of inducing farmers to settle there, and the enormous oost of maintaining them, added to the heavy taxation at home, made many grumble before the Herero rising. When this happened, there was a loyal oo-operation to end the rebellion, and not a little joy that foreigners would have an opportunity of seeing the calibre of the Army. But now that nothing brilliant has been done, and the guerilla warfare drags on from month to month, a reaction has set in that may turn the trend of thought from expansion abroad to reform at home.

div.head: THE TSAR’S MANIFESTO.
INDIFFERENCE OF THE PEOPLE
EDUCATED CLASSES DISQUALIFIED.
div.p: Sr. Petersburg, August 21.

The complete absence of enthusiasm is the most striking feature of the Russian press comments regarding the Assembly project. There are no signs of rejoicing anywhere. The high rental qualification of the town voters excludes the majority of the educated classes. Only 5,000 inhabitants in St Petersburg are qualified. Rioting took place at Kichineff following the publication of the project Several thou- sand demonstrators were dispersed by the mounted police. (Reuter)
St. Petersburg, August 21.
The Tsar’s manifesto has been greeted with indifference. (Havas)

div.head: IS IT PEACE?
FURTHER CONCESSIONS IMPOSSIBLE.
div.p: London, August 21.

According to a telegram received yesterday evening from Portsmouth (N.H.), the "Times” learns that the Tsar held a Council at which it was finally decided that no further concessions can be made. (Reuter)

div.head: WARSAW AND LODZ STRIKE.
THE POPULACE INDIGNANT.
div.p: Warsaw, August 21. A general strike has been proclaimed here owing to the indignation caused by the pro- cedure in connection with the elections, which will treat the Poles in a similar manner to the Asiatic nomade. (Reuter)
St. Petersburg, August 21.
A general strike at Warsaw and Lodz is reported. (Havas)

div.head: RUSSIAN LIBERALS ARRESTED.
div.p: St. Petersburg, August 21.
Professor Milioskow and ten other well- known liberals have been arrested. (Havas)

div.head: INDIA'S NEW VICEROY.
div.p: FROM CANADA TO INDIA.
London, August 21.
(Official). Lord Minto will sucoeed Visoount Curzon. (Reuter)

The new Vioeroy of India is son of the third Earl of Minto. Born on July 9,1847, he was educated at Eton and Trinity College, Cam- bridge. An ensign in the Scots Guards in 1867, he saw active service with the Turkish Army in 1877, and in the second Afghan war in 1879. He acted as private secretary to Lord Roberts during the latter’s brief visit to the Cape in 1881, volunteered for the Egyptian campaign in 1885, and was military secretary to the Marquis of Lansdowne while the present Foreign Minister was Governor General of Canada in 1883-85. In 1885 he was chief of the staff during the hard fought little campaign against the rebellious Indians and half-breds in the north-west of the Dominion. He con- tested Hexham in 1886, and in 1891 succeeded to the title. He was created G.C.M.G. in 1898, in which year he was appointed Governor- General of Canada, a post which he filled with consistent sucoess till 1904, when he was suc- ceeded by Earl Grey. Lord Minto married, in 1885, Mary, daughter of General the Hon. Charles Grey.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
NO FURTHER REDUCTION.
div.p: London, August 21.
It is notified that the Army Council does not intend to carry out any further reduction of the British garrison in Egypt. (Reuter)

div.head: THE EAST AFRICAN RISING.
div.p: GERMANY SENDS TROOPS.
Berlin, August 21.
Owing to the rising in East Africa, the Government is despatching 160 marines, to- gether with machine guns and two small cruisers. (Reuter)

div.head: YELLOW FEVER ABATING.
div.p: New Orleans, August 21.
Owing to rigorous preventive measures, the yellow fever is abating. (Reuter)

div.head: Quarantine
div.p: Arrivals from Adalia are now subjected to a medical visit only.

div.head: Greek Philharmonic Society
div.p: A concert will be given by this society to-morrow evening, commencing at 9 p.m.

div.head: Delta Barrage
div.p: A building for models is to be constructed at the Delta Barrage in the near future.

div.head: The Post Office at Sennar
div.p: is now opened to foreign ordinary, inland ordinary, and telegraphic money service.

div.head: Commercial Treaties
div.p: It is hoped that the commercial treaty between Egypt and Italy will be signed in November.
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Imam distriot of Cairo during to-morrow night and at dawn of the 23rd inst. will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: Yesterday’s plague bulletin reoords one now admission to hospital at Port Baid, and the recovery of the solitary case at

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 16 vessels passed through the Canal on the 18th inst., 11 of whioh wereBritish, 1 German, 2 French, 1 Turkish, 1 Austrian. The day's reoeipts were frs. 424,603.23 making the total from the 1st inst frs. 5,580,764.21.

div.head: Injured by a Buffalo
div.p: A startled buffalo cow ran down a man and woman on Sonday in Moharrem Bey quarter. The woman was severely injured and requires fifteen days treatment The man came cff comparatively lightly.

div.head: A Brutal Husband
div.p: On Sunday a certain Hassan Aisa Ali hurled a lighted lamp at his wife Zanouba, who had asked him for some money for household expenses, irflicting serious burns on the poor woman, who has bad to be removed to hospital.

div.head: Killed by Scorpions
div.p: Two more deaths from the stings of scorpions are reported from Cairo, a child having died from this cause in the Darb el Ahmar quarter, and another in Old Cairo, where such fatalities have been comparatively common of late.

div.head: Injured at Play
div.p: A lad' named Ismail Abd el Moneim, 11 years of age, was flying his kite from the roof of a house at El Halwagi, near the Customs, on Sunday, when he made a false step, and fell into the attest, sustaining injuries that necessitate ten days’ medical treatment.

div.head: Attempted Murder
div.p: A Cairene butcher named Ahmed el Habashi recently quarrelled in the course of an argument with Hafzallah Mankarius and stabbed him in the abdomen. The polioe of the Khalifa kism have sinoe arrested the would-be murderer, whose victim has been taken to hospital.

div.head: The Sarkis Affair
div.p: We are glad to hear that the Armenian community of Alexandria has decided to send the two yoonggirls concern- ed in this painful affair to an Armenian oonvent for orphans at Constantinople. The "decision does great credit to the humanity andoommon sense of our Armenian fellow oitizens.

div.head: The Alhambra Theatre
div.p: To-morrow night the Della Guardia Dramatic Company will present Le Pillole cCErcole at this theatre. Lorde'a drama La Dormiente will be given very shortly and the oompany also bills Pam- ela Marchande de Frivolitfi to appear soon. Subscription tiokets may be obtained at the box-office of the theatre.

div.head: Hashish Seizures
div.p: Six turbos of hashish were found in a sack of flower by the Customs authorities yesterday, whilst on Saturday two women named Luisa Moretti and Elena Cassa- pido while returning from the S.S. Imperator Nioolai were arrested by the quay polioe. The female searcher emp'oyed discovered eight turbas of hashish oonoealed in their skirts.

div.head: Tne Liege Exhibition
div.p: Among the mem- bers of the Jury of the International Exhibition at liege we notice the name of Mr. Collonge, director general of Berlitz Sohools. This official nomination is still another homage rendered to a celebrated institution, and to a system whioh has rendered possible such progress in the study of modem languages. 26347-1

div.head: British Chamber of Commerce
div.p: We would draw the attention of manufacturers and mer- chants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Bgypt, which was formed in 1896 with the sole object of assisting British trade in this country. The services of the Chamber are always at the disposal of any member desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appoint- ing suitable agents. As no fee is oharged for I such advice, it is obviously in the interests of j all British traders here to beoome members, especially when it is remembered that the annual subecription is merely the nominal one • £1. The latter payment also includes a oopy | of the monthly Journal issued by the Chamber j Home enquirers oan obtain farther particulars from oar London offioe, 86, New Broad-street which acts as agents to the Chamber.

div.head: THE SULTAN’S ACCESSION. DINNER AT RAS EL TIN.
div.p: Invitations will be issued this week by the Cabinet of the Grand Master of Ceremonies for the banquet whioh will be given by the Acting Regent at Ras el Tin Palace on Sep- tember 1st Among the guests will be the ministers, advisers and under-secretaries of state, the Diplomatic Agents of the Domains Administration, and the Caisse de la Dette, the State Railways and other Administrations, General Bullock, the Acting Governor of Alexandria, and the Consuls of the Powers at Alexandria.

div.head: THE YEMEN RISING.
div.p: In his report on the reoent action at Sebk-el- Hamis, Marshal Ahmed Faizi Pasha, Com- mander of the Ottoman forces in the Yemen, states that the action lasted from 8 a.m. to midday, and that the retreating rebels left many dead behind them. Tarkish authority is re-established at Menakhkha.

div.head: THE COTTON-WORM.
div.p: This bulletin issued by the Ministry of the Interior for the week ending last Saturday again shows a very considerable decrease in the area of land in which the cotton-worm still exists. The following are the reports from the four affected provinces.
Gharbieh :—825 feddans, belonging to 68 proprietors, have been affested by the worm, and 811 of these have been cleared by 718 children.
Behera :—2,396 feddans, belonging to 48 proprietors, have been affected, and 2,804 have been cleared by 6,641 children.
Dakahlieh :—109 feddans, belonging to 45 proprietors, have been affected, and 102 cleared by 810 children.
Damietta :—9} feddans, belonging to 9 proprietors, have been affected, and have all been cleared by 61 children.

Comparing the above with the report of last week, we find that the number of affected provinces is reduced by one, Kalionbieh being now entirely free from the worm. In the Gharbieh province tho number of affected feddans shows a decrease of 814, in Dakahlieh a decrease of 13, in Damietta a decrease of 11}, and in Behora an inorease of 1,141 feddans. The increase in the number of feddans attacked in the Behera provinoe must in no way be taken to indicate a general increase, for it must be remembered that this provinoe has suffered much more severely, not only during the present year,but also in former ones, than any other, and in the reports ofeaoh week we have noted a considerable numerical difference between the areas attacked and those cleared. It is obvious that the insect is much more strongly established in this province than in any other. Those who know the Prodenia littoralit find it one of tho commonest of the moths whioh fly round lamps or eleotrio lights at night in Alexandria and the neighbourhood.

div.head: SUMMER LEAVES.
div.p: Leave of absence has been granted to the following officials of the Sudan Government and Army Officers until the undermentioned dates :— El Kaimakam Carter Bey, officer command- ing 9th Sudanese, until 29th September ; El g.;m»Viun Cameron Bey, senior inspector of the Sennar provinoe until 1st October; El Bimbashi Arden, 4th battalion, until 29th September ; El Bimbashi Elderton, deputy assistant financial recretary until 15th Septem- ber ; El Bimbashi Mayne, D.S.O.. 18th Sudan- eie, until 2nd October; El Bimbashi Cox, 3rd battalion, until 2nd Ootober ; El Bim- bashi Rawson, 15th Sudanese, until 29th October. Leave in extension has been granted to El Kaimakam Garsia Bey, D.S.O., department of supplies, until 20th September ; to El Bimbashi Dale, deputy assistant director of posts and telegraphs, until 29th October ; and to El Bimbashi Heath, Camel Corps, until 4th Ootober.

div.head: THE LATE MENSHAWI PASHA.
div.p: Dissensions and disputes having arisen of late between the heirs to the immense properties left by Ahmed Menshawi Pasha, the wealthy landed proprietor who died suddenly in Cairo some months ago, three native nota- bles have been appointed arbitrators by the Meglis El Haaby.They are Ismail Pasha Abaza, Hassan Pasha Rassim and Saad Bey Zsglool. The heirs are the lady Fatma Amen,the widow, daughter of the late Abdalla Pasha Inglisi, an Englishman, a daughter, and two sons, one of whom is at Tourah serving a long term of imprisonment on a charge of murder. The late Menshawi Pasha left properties whioh give, it is reported, an annual income of £40,000 at least, but a portion of his large estates were handed over to the Wekfs for the benefit of the poor and certain mosques. Itiscertain clauses in his will that have been the oause of the dissensions between the members of his family, who are seeking to set aside some of them. The son, who is now in prison was, it appeals, disinherited, and he is also disputing the will, but it is hoped and expeoted that the arbitrators reoently named will be able to settle the difference that have arisen and satisfy all the interested parties.

div.head: CAIRO TRAMWAYS. CONDITIONS OF CONCESSION.
div.p: Monday’s 'Official Journal' oontains the text of the oonoession granted to the Cairo Tram- ways Company by the Egyptian Government We have already described the routes to be followed by the new lines, and will oonfine ourselves to mentioning the principal condi- tions imposed by the Government whioh are of considerable interest The Tramways Company undertakes to use ao rails in the future but those of the •Ph«nix’ type of 68 kilogrammes per metre, and to replace the rails at present in use by the above mentioned type by Deoember 81,1990, at latest The Pyramids Une,however, will form an exoeption to this rule, for the rails of the "Vignol” type will be retained in use between Kasrel Nil and Mena House. Of the tramways the Saptieh and Shoubra lines are to be completed and working within two Cof the signature of the oonoession (i.e. July 18, 1906), the Sahel (Rod el Fang) line within five yean, and the Ghamrah and Abattoirs lines within one year from the abora date. The doubling of the old Cairo line is to be completed by the end of this month, greatly to the relief, we imagine, of all who live near the Kasr el Aini Road. The line from Foum el Khalig to the Southern bridge over the small branch of the Nile will be constructed oonourrently with the widening of the road by the Tan rim. The Ghizeh line across Rodah Island and the new bridges will be completed as soon as the bridges are open to heavy traffic, and the Imam-el-Shaffdi line is to be completed within fifteen yean from the 18th ult. The minimum radius of all ourves is fixed at 25 metres, exospt in special cases which the Ministry of Publio Works will determine. The speed of the trams is not to exceed twelve kilometres an hour and must be reduced at all points where the Ministry of Publio Works oonsiden a lower speed necessary in the interests of publio safety. The new and the previous oonoessions expire simultaneously, viz. on Deoember 6, 1951, when the whole of the properties of the Tramways Company will fall to the Government

div.head: MENA HOUSE.
div.p: There -have been persistent rumours for some time in Cairo that the Mena House Hotel and the surrounding property of some 100 feddans, belonging to Mrs. Locke-King, widow of the late owner, had been acquired by, or were under option to, the Nnngovioh Hotels Company, but we are informed that snob is not the fact The foots of the oase are that an offer of pur- chase for £>20,000 was reoently made by the representatives of an English syndicate to the lady’s agent, bat was refuted, and sinoe then it was pffered to the above oompany at a slightly higher prioe, whioh offer was not, bow- The original hotel bnildings and the different additions and improvements made sinoe have, it is said, cost from first to last £80,000. The hotel is held by Mr. E. Weokel, the present proprietor manager, on a ten yean’ lease, of which about seven years are expired, at an annoal rental of £4,000. There is no like- lihood of there being any immediate ohange, however, in the ownership of the property, as Mr. Weokel, who is now at Luoerne, has just sent out orders for all the repairs necessary for the reopening of the hotel on the 1st November to be proceeded with at once.

div.head: THE COMING ECLIPSE.
div.p: The Survey Department has issued through the Preea Bureau in Cairo the following in- teresting particulars regarding the ooming eclipse of the sun. The oentral line of the total eclipse of August 80 will pass near the railway station of Kbat- tara, about 12 kilometres north of Assouan ; the phenomena will be visible as a total eolipee from near Bdfn to near the village of Dakka, aouth of Assouan ; north and south of this area the eolipee will be partial, and at Cairo about nine-tenths of the enn’s disc will be oovered. The eolipee will oommenoe in Cairo at fonr minutes past three, at thirteen minutes past four it will have reaohed its middle, and the end will be at fifteen minutes past five. The time will not differ greatly in the Nila Valley localities.

div.head: EGYPTIAN GOVERNMENT TELEGRAPHS.
div.p: After several postponements occasioned by delay in the completion of the premises, the oentral Government telegraph offioe in Cairo is to be transferred on the 1st September to the new bnildings in the 8haria Boulak belonging to the Daira Khasea, whioh have been taken on a ten yean’ lrase at a rental of LE. 500 per annum. The new offices will oooupy part of the ground floor and are an immense improvement on the old ones, whioh had become much too small for the great inorease of bosioess especially sinoe the open- ing of the Cairo bonne two years ago.

div.head: STAMPED PAPER. A CASH FOR REFORM.
div.p: Whenever boe turns to the “Official Gazette" for information ra tenders, sales of public laud etc. etc., the formula-tenders must be sub- mitted on stamped paper* appears in every notice. Under these dreams tonoee it —»m« to unobtainable at the Gonvernorat of Alexandria except in quantities of 1,000 or more sheets at a time. For smaller quantities the buyer mast go to the Post Offioe, or to a small shop in the Tarkish market quite half-an-honr's walk from the Gonvernorat We oannot help thinking that the oonvenienoe of the publio would be better served, if the indispensible sheets of “papier timbed" were procurable at the Gonvernorat. Alexandria, be it remembered, is a town of long distances, and the foot that stamped paper is obtainable in the Souk-el-Turki and at the Post Offioe is not very comforting to persons who are equidistant from both these places, and, when applying to the Gouvernorat, are informed that,their needs cannot be served unless they oare to take a thousand sheets, —more than enough to last the ordinary man for a lifetime.

div.head: S.S. GIBRALTAR AGAIN ON FIRE.
div.p: (From our Correspondent.) Suez, Monday. The cargo of the S.S. Gibraltar whioh was on fire at Suez lest Thursday afternoon, suddenly took fire again on Saturday after noon, and again yesterday. Thanks to prompt assistance, the fire was soon extinguished by flooding the bold, and the vessel is now discharging the damaged oargo in lighten, in order to avoid similar probable outbreaks.

div.head: A NEW MOSS LINER.
div.p: Messrs. Archibald M’Millan and Son, limit- ed, shipbuilders, Dumbarton, laanohed on the 8th inst the steel screw steamer Menepthah, whioh they have built to the order of the Moss Steamship Co., Liverpool (Messrs. James Moss and Co.) for their Mediterranean trade. The vessel, whioh has been built to Lloyd’s highest class, is of the following dimensions Length 315 feet, breadth 44 feet 6 inches, depth moulded 25 feet 5 inches, and is fitted with all the latest improvements for the rapid and efficient working of cargo. Large and airy state rooms have been fitted amidships for the accommodation of first-class passengers, for whom also is provided cm the bridge deck a handsomely fitted entranoe hall louDge, and smokeroom. Over these is fitted a large pro- menade deck, on whioh is plaoed the captain’s accommodation and chart-room. The aeoond- olass passengers are aooommodated aft in the poop, and the offioen and engineers’ rooms are fitted under the bridge deck The vessel is lighted by electricity throughout, and ample refrigerating chambers have been fitted for the preservation of provisions. The machinery is of the triplo-explanaion type. The vessel and machinery have been superintended during construction by Messrs. William Bsplen and Son, Liverpool, and the christening oeremony was performed by Miss Harding, of Stanton, Bebington, Cheshire.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: Hie Moss liner Nitocris arrived yesterday morning from Glasgow with passengers, mails and general cargo. The Khedivial Mail Steamship Assouan will leave Alexandria at 4 p.m. on Saturday and Port Said at 4 p.m. on Sunday for Beyrouth, Tripoli, Mersina, Alexandre tta, Larnaoa, Li- massol, Cai'ffa and Jaffa.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Sir Francis O’Calteghan, who, after leaf railway eervioe in indie, beoame merging director of the Uganda Railway, it oomi^ oat in Ootober to Cairo on hie way to Uganda.

div.head: THE NICOSIA CHURCH.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gaxhte. Sir,—I was glad to read in a reoent Dumber of your esteemed journal that the little Anglican Church, at Niooaia, Cyprus, haa been greatly improved, as regards deoorations. It is a nioe little church and what puzzles me, is why no steps have ever been tafan to organise a proper choir. Probably they have one by now, but when I was these last-nr no snoh thing existed. On my enquiring why they did not have one, I was told that then were not enough people, or some such excuse. Surely there must be four gentlemen and four or five ladies in Niooaia who oan zing 1 If they were to pnetioe onoe a week, as is ifong at the English Churoh here, I believe they would be able to oonduot the servioe chorally, whioh is always nioe, and I am sore the dwp- lain would prefer it Very often the choir at St. Mark’s only numbers about six pessons, and yet they are able to oonduot tho servioe very well I do not therefore see why no steps should be taken to furnish the ohurok at Nioosia with a choir. The late Ven. Archdaaoon 8penoer, very often mentioned that it was a pity no ohoir existed—only it seems he did not try to get one np. The climate is very healthy, and I am surprised to find snoh a comparatively small British oommunity. I am told that nothing goes ahead in Cyprus, and that all who have from time to time establish- ed businesses there had to sell np and leave. I am always interested in anything that deals with Cyprus. 1 am, Sir, etc, A Well-Wisher of Cyprus. Alexandria, August 16.

div.head: CREDIT FONCIER SHARES.
div.p: Te the Editor of the Egyptian Qaam. Sir,—As there may be soma holders of Credit Foncier Egyptian thane here whom it interests, I would oall attention to a very oariont feature in the quotations of their shares reoently issued in Paris. There appears to be an attempt to lower their prioe until after the new issue. Within the test ten days Paris quotation was frs. 815. An order sent to eight brokers in Paris to buy at 8l8gaveno execution, but the prioe row to 822, than on no order being sent prioe was redwood to 816. An order was sent to bay at 819, and a few shares wertf given and prioe was raised to 821, again no order was sent and prioe went np to 816, orders sent at 818 but no shares sold, and we dose at 891. A Haves rumour rays a great financier is striving to make the Credit Fonder shareholders abstain from tbs new issue, ao that the Daira 8anieh shareholders may get a big interest in the Credit Fonder, and thow who had Daira interest may retain an interest in Egyptian affaire, instead being paid off in otah. Henoe this oonstant marking down of prioes without sales. Perhaps this note may save a Credit Fonder shareholder. I ass, Sir, etc., Lux. Alexandria, August 22.

div.head: Conseil quarantenalre
div.p: Mr. ledblbgub sanitaire d'Allemagne a com- munique b la prisidence du conseil quarante- naire un loDg rapport au sujet des vibrions, trouvis cette annie dans l'intestin de quelques pblerins dioidis b Tor. Le rapport est envoji-pr M. le Directeurde rinstitut Royal pour les maladies infeotieuses. En voici le risumb : Comme suite b ma deroibre communication j'ai l’tonneur desoumettre un rapport dbtaillb b propoe du mime sujet par M. le professear Kolle et M. le Dr. Meinicke, assistants de l’lnstitut. J'avais dit qu’il serait b ddsirer quo lesoul- tnres de Tor fussent donnies b l'lnstitut des maladies infeotieuses pour y itre soumises b un examen sbrieux. Le President du Conseil Sanitaire b rbpondu trbs obligeamment b ma demands et a autorisi M. Gottschlioh b nous les envoyer. Il s’agit, en tout, de 6 vibrions provenant de 6 oadavres de pblerins. Aprbs les reoherches trbs soigneuses et trbs minutieuses das profeareura Drs. Kolle et Mei- niche, je partage l’opinion des experts baoti riologues d’Egypte qui disent qu’il s’agit, sans ancon doute, dans tons ces cm, des vbri tables vibrions de cholbra. Li riiultat de l’examen bactdrio'ogiqae ne pent mbme pas itre ibranlb par le fait que pendant le pblerinage a-ieun cas n’a iti oons- tatb qta ressemblt au cholbra an point de vue olinique ou anaq.mo pathologique. Nop* saviona «4ja qua des personnes ayant M exposbes b lmfeotion, peuvent hbberger les germes spboifiques du oholira dans leurs intestine sans montrer oliniquement les moin- Nous sevioas aussi par des observations antbrieures que des portenrs de oholira peuvent Mae altb ration visible de leur eanti hbberger dene leurs intestine pendant 7 ou 8 surnames des vibrions oepables de se repro- inirf,

Les observations. lie Tor, sous apprennent que oe temps pent itre, selon les ciroonstanoes, encore plus long, etqoe, mime, plusieura porteurs de cholera u'oooasionnent pas ton jours la maladisi dans Icsr eetourage. Pour le moment il nous est impossible de trencher la question do savoir si les vibrions de choleraperdent peu b pea lsur virolenoe poor d’aatres pereonnes par lesejoat prolonge dans l'intestin d'un homme, fait pour lequel parlent quelquessymptOmesde digiuiresoence observes sur certaines de oes 6 ooloniee. Dans le cas qui nous interease, il feat aussi se reudre oompte qu’il est plus quo probable que les pblerins r asses et taros hibergeant en eox le germe de la maladie, n'ont pas provo- qui des cas de oholira dans lour entourage pareeque les vibrions itaient. trbs nres ou une occasion favorable a manqui poor les re- porter sur des individos accessible* b la • mala- die. Il faut reconnaltre que, pour le oonseil sa- nitaire d’Alexandria, dee dioouvertes oomme cedes de Tor font surgir de groiseidiffioultbs. De quelque maniire qua l’on veuille lee ri- soudre il faut apprbder dans toute sa valour l’ipreuve dela priienoedevibrionsoholbriques, cher dea pblerins, mume si aucuucas de oholira n’a iti observe. div.head: EGYPTIAN PRISONS.
div.p: COLES PASHAS REPORT.

PRISON OFFENCES. (Continued from the 14th inst) 07 prisoners escaped daring the year 1904, 43 were recaptnrtd, and 19 are still at large. In 19C3 there wore 65 escapes. The following table gives the parrionlats 6f the escapes for the past three years. 1901. 1903. 1902. Escaped from prison pre- cinct*...............r 16 92 15 Licaped 'from warders outside......... 28 16 17 Escaped from polioe guards outsicfe....... 23 28 28 Of the prisoners who escaped and remain- ed uncaptnred at the close of the year:— 4, had over three years’ imprisonment to . complete. 1 had over one year and less than two. 3 had under one year. 4 had.nnder six months. 7 bad under three months. . Three of the four prisoners with long sen- tences escaped from Assiont prison whilst em- ployed in building the now prison. These prisoners should not have been so employed. The fourth escaped from polioe oustody at Simbellawein. Prison punishments. Table XIV (previously published) shows tho punishments awarded lor prison offences and if wo compare them with punishments awarded in the two previous years we find:— 1904. 1903. 1902. Transferred to a Penal Servitude Prison . . . 35 29 21 Corporal punishment ex- ceeding 24 laahes . . . 6 19 35 Corporal punishment not exoeoding24 laahes. 64 114 233 Further terms of impri- sonment by Tribunals. 19 22 24 Minor punishments . . . 6,628 5,854 5,119 The continued decrease in corporal punish- ment is very satisfactory. VITAL. The report of the Principal Medical Officer with statistics (Tables XV. to XIX.) will be found in the appendix. Dr. Kirton has at my request dealt at considerable length with the various causes tending to increase sickness and mortality in the Central Prisons and has anal>sed the returns practically from every point of view. I think that the tables he has worked out are well worth the attention of Medical and Sanitary experts. Mortality. It will be seen that the mortality has drop- ped to 19.8 per thousand mile, with one excep- tion (1901 with 17.3) to the lowest yet reached. Tuberculosis is still the cause of a large ncmber (32) of deaths,and may, I suppose, be attributed to the • overcrowding throughout this and previous years, notwithstanding that little or no fault can now be found with the ventilation. In fact if it had not been for the practically perfect ventilation it would have been impossible to haveaooom- modated all the prisoners committed to prison daring the year. Deaths stated to be due to diseases of the digestive system, diarrhoea, eta, amount to 85, the largest number yet recorded in any one year. In this respect it is rather remarkable that September (when the Nile is in full flood) was the most unhealthy and January, February and March the healthiest mnntha An outbreak of typhus occurred in Beni- Suef during the spring and aooounted for 12 deaths, otherwise the prisons have been free from any epidemia I agree with Dr. Kirton that consideriug that typhus has been pre- valent in Egypt more or less throughout the year and that every prison has been very muoh overcrowded, it shows great care on the part of the Medical Offioera that no other serious outbreak occurred. The health oj newly admitted prisoners. An appreciable percentage of the deaths occurred within the first month of imprison- ment, thirty, per oent. within first six months and fifty per sent, within the first year. It may be argued therefore that a large percentage of the deaths occurred amongst prisoners who were in bad health on entering a prison. On the other hand the fact that a prisoner’s mode ol life is entirely changed on imprieoment must not altogether be ignored, and in some instan- ces at all events this sadden change is probablj itself the cause of a prisoner’s health breaking down. Personally I am inclined to think that sleep- ing on straw mats, with asphalt floors and thorough ventilation must be very trying to a prisoner aooastomed to bedding or even to the mud floor of an ill-ventilated hut But the queition is whether any change in this respeot would not make the prisons too popular. As it is with the ameliorated diet we are danger- ously near the line when imprisonment will altogether oease to be deterrent to the lower classes. Severity of imprisonment f or weUdo do persons. In Egypt one law for both the rich and poor works out very unfairly, as the modes of life vary so, that what is little short of torture to one may be comparative luxury to another, yet it cannot be weU left to a prison official or ' vdn to a judge to discriminate. It is some satisfaction to feel that if in the case of th. well-to-do the punishment is relatively very severe, he is as a rule lees deserving of sym- pathy and has not the same motive for oom- pri-ting crime as one from the lower classes. (To be continued.)

div.head: THE BONMARTINI TRIAL.
div.p: (From a Corrrbpohdkht.) At last 1 After dragging its slow length along for but one month short of three years, tho Bonmartini case has come to an end, and the verdict is given. The story is a curious one and phsyoo- logists have found interesting matter for study in the characters of the people concerned. It will be remembered that on the 2nd September, 1909, the body of Count Bonmar- tini was found lying in the ante-room of his apartment in Bologna. Although no less than seventeen wounds were oounted on thebodr, proving the savage ness of the attaok, it was evident that there bad been no straggle, for the dead man’s clothes were in perfect order, wherever the assassin’s knife had not penetrated. The Count had evidently been overpowered before he had been able to make any defenoe and, from the nature of the wounds, the experts were of opinion that two if not more, were oonoerned in the murder. A letter found on the table, the disorder of the apartment, and the fact that the Coun- tess's jewellery had been stolen, seemed to leave no possibility of doubt that the Count has fallen a victim in a guet-apens laid for him by some woman and her aooomplioea. The Countess, and her brother Tullio Murri, added evidenoe that oonfiimed this view. Count Bonmartini had married in 1892 the daughter of Professor Murri, a physioian whose name is famous all over Italy. The first six years of their married life were spent happily enough in Padua, but, when in 1898 they settled in Bologna, where Bonmartini wished to study medicine, differences broke out between husband and wife, in which Bologna society took the wife’s side so strongly that the Connt soon found himself looked upon askanoe by most of his former friends. Not knowing what reports his wife was spreading about him, we eee in the poor man's diary how puuled he was by the attitnde of those around him. Meanwhile Conntess Linda was being proclaimed a saint and martyr, a dovoted mother, and an injured wife. At last a separa- tion was decided on. This lasted three years, at the end of which time the Count threatened to go to law if his children, a boy and girl, were not restored to him, and his wife, knowing he must gain his cause, consented, to the poor man's grest joy, to resume life with him under certain oouditions. This was in April 1902. Towards the end of July, Bonmartini finding life, intolerable in Bologna, determined to return to his nativo town of Padna. Thereupon he was denounced by all his wife’s family as the would-be murder- ed of the unfortunate Linda, and Tnllio says he felt his blood boil when he heard of this intolerable oraelty. Such language was some- what exaggerated when it is remembered that Bologna is within a lew hours of Padua, and that the Connt had offered his wife a season ticket to enable her to be with her family as muoh as she liked. This was at the end of July.and on the 28th August, Bonmartini was murdered. The Coun- tess was at Venioe with her ohildren at the time, and that very day she had aooompanied her husband to the station after a lunch “en fmille” to oelebrate his birthday. Linda had annoncoed her husband’s arrival to one Rosina Bonetti, a woman of the lowest extraction, her brother Tallio’s mistress, to whom Linda wrote in terms of affectionate intimacy I Daring the first few days the police made one important disoovery. In the house in whioh the Bonmartinia lived, they found a small apartment, let to a mysterious individual who had never been seen to enter it The polioe found there some tattles of wine aim lar to one left behind by the assassins in the Counts apartment, and, among some rubbish, two torn envelopes addressed to a Dr. Secchi, who is well-known in Bologna. Two days after the disoovery of the body, Linda, after a short and harried examination, had left for Switzerland with her ohildren and brother, not even waiting for her husbands funeral. The polioe oontinued their researches, but without any very definite results, when on the 11th September all Bologna was startled by hearing that Professor Murri, had handed to the police a letter from his son Tullio in which he deolared himself not guilty of the mordsr of his brother in law, but of having killed him in self-defence. He related how on the evening of the 28th August he had met the Connt in his house and had expostulated with him on the way he treated Linda, that the Connt had thereupon rushed at him with a knife whioh, he, in self-defence, had tamed on the Connt, and with whioh he had killed him. In a fit of fary, he ooald not aoooaat for he had straok Again and again at the dead body. Whan he had reoovored his self oontrol he had forged the letter found, broken open the drawers and taken his sister jawellery away in order to mislead the police. The next day Rosina was arrested, and two days later the Countess herself, who mean- while had returned to Bologna as saddenly as she had left. No ore knew where Tullio was. but on hearing of his sister's arrest be gave himself up on the 18th. The disoovery of the envelopes addressed toSeoohi had started the polioe on a new trail of evidenoe. They discovered that the rent of the snail apartment had been paid by Tire Borghi, a servsnt of Seoohi’s, who said the money h»d been given her by the Conntess !l In a small town like Bologna, where the Mnrris were known to all, it was no mystery that ye>r« before, when Linda was a girl of 16 there bad been certain love passages between her and 8eosbi, nipped in the bud by her- parents’ d reppronl, Tie*, now, in oross examination, deolared that suoe the Bonmar -inis had returned to Bologna the lovers had met again, and that she, Tisa,had acted as go- between, and that the little apartment had been taken by them as a convenient meeting place.. Linda confronted with this evidenoe, denied nothing. She even acknowledged it with the womanly dignity of whioh she is so perfect a mistress. "I am oonvinoed”, she said, "that no one cam blame anything in my oonduot as sinoeour reconciliation my husband allowed me entire liberty of action" 111 Some days before Tullio had given himself up, the polioe had made another arrest, that of an oubat-elbows doctor, gambler, good-for- nothing, ready to do anybody’s dirty work at the lowest prioe. This man, a friend of Tullio's, and seen with him several times on the days proceeding the murder, had left Bologna suddenly on the night it was oommitted and as it was ascertained, in possession o^ior him a considerable sum of money. Naldi at once 11 acknowledged that he knew Tullio had deter mined to get rid of his brother-in-law, and had fried to persuade him to give him a help- ing hand, but this Naldi had not only refuted to do, but raised every argument to prevail on Tullio to renounce his intention. He accounted for the money in his possession in different j ways. His last version being that he had stolen throughout having any aooompUoes. Tho next few months brought nothing of special interest in the way of evidenoe. then, that against Dr. Seoofai was not yet strong enough to justify his arrest but, bsfore the 23rd June, 190*. the polioe had piooed together what they required, and Seochi was in prison.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu’au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: “Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.
